article.title: Debris Disc Constraints on Planetesimal Formation

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model predicts weaker planetesimals (with radii between the pebble size and about one kilometer)?
choices: Both models predict similar strength for these sizes.
The figure doesn't provide information to answer this.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed line in this figure represent?
choices: The slope for equal mass in all logarithmic size bins.
The Dohnanyi slope for small solids.
The slope for equal cross section of solids in all logarithmic size bins.
The expected slope for large planetesimals after gas dispersal.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does a higher M1/M2 ratio imply about the initial size distribution of planetesimals?
choices: A larger fraction of mass is contained within smaller planetesimals (population 1).
A larger fraction of mass is contained within larger planetesimals (population 2).
The total disc mass (M1 + M2) increases.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the initial increase in disc brightness for the M1/M2 = 1/500 model?
choices: Delayed stirring of the planetesimal disc.
The model assumes pebble-pile planetesimals, which produce dust more efficiently.
The disc needs time to produce enough dust through collisions of larger planetesimals.
The presence of a significant warm dust component closer to the star.
